author: christopherhope

text:
These options are either an "exhaustive ballot process" (similar to selecting a Speaker) or a "preferential ballot" which lets MPs rank the options. 

The least popular is eliminated and preferences transferred until a consensus choice emerges. This will be how Brexit is sorted.
author: christopherhope

text:
Next week's indicative votes sound like how viewers decide the winner of the X Factor.

EU options will be put to MPs, with the one with the fewest votes dropped until the House of Commons ends up with a single choice.

It will mean that MPs will vote for something. But what?
author: christopherhope

text: Greg Clark appears to be daring Theresa May to fire him on tonight's Political Thinking Podcast with @bbcnickrobinson.

text:
But it wasn't, was it? 

The PM clearly expressed the frustration in her statement with the Brexit situation felt by voters.

The question is now whether she will grasp this problem and be decisive enough to get the UK out of this mess.
author: christopherhope

text:
Warning her not to delay Brexit if she values "our grassroots", the two-page letter calls on Mrs May to seek “legally binding changes to the Withdrawal Act, e.g. a unilateral exit clause, a legal end date or Malthouse Alternative Arrangements”.
#Brexit

text:
One source said: "All bar three [of the speakers] said 'she has to go'. They kept saying 'she is coming to the 1922 tomorrow, she has got to be told this'."

The insider added: "If she goes tonight, tonight will be the night when somebody stands up and says 'you have got to go'."
author: christopherhope

text:
Last night's meeting of the European Research Group was explosive.

All but three of the 20 MPs who spoke at the 80-strong meeting demanded she quits. One source said it "was the worst yet from the leadership's point of view".

More at @HarryYorke1's blog
author: christopherhope

text: Tonight could interesting. Theresa May has been told by her backbench MPs it would be a "good idea" if she comes to tonight's 1922 committee meeting in wake of Brexit delay, sources say in the wake of the likely Brexit delay

text: Thunder and lightning and hail  over Soho, central London right now. And Brexit is now legally just 12 days away.
author: christopherhope

text:
Big question is why anyone fighting for Brexit support in the upcoming Tory leadership election would back Theresa May's deal now. 
The longer they hold out - the better their chances among the grassroots. 
Leader of the pack @DominicRaab will know this.
author: christopherhope

text: No wonder Team Barnier are feeling reportedly "depressed". They helped to negotiate a deal that would never get through the Commons. Two years wasted.
author: christopherhope

text:
It's all in today's Sunday Telegraph splash:

DUP demands seat at the table in future EU trade talks as price for backing May's deal https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/16/dup-demands-seat-table-future-eu-trade-talks-price-backing-mays/?WT.mc_id=tmg_share_tw … via @Telegraph
author: christopherhope

text:
Don't be distracted by talk of money for the DUP. That comes after June when the next Confidence and Supply deal is done.
For now DUP has two demands from the talks:
1) A guarantee Britain and NI -are treated the same by EU 
2) A seat in the future trade talks between UK and EU.
author: christopherhope

text:
Parties are warned that the period when donations are regulated by the Commission started on Jan 23 and runs until election day, May 23.

The prospect of the European Parliament elections is now very real.
author: christopherhope

text: The Electoral Commission guidance tells parties hoping to stand candidates: "On 23 May 2019 voters in the United Kingdom will cast their ballot to elect 73 Members of the European Parliament."
author: christopherhope

text:
The elections would trigger a likely return to British politics for Nigel Farage, the former Ukip leader who is backing a new Brexit party to field candidates.

The irony is that David Cameron called the 2016 EU referendum to destroy Farage once and for all.
author: christopherhope

text:
This is not a drill.

Fresh guidance running to 23 pages has been made available to political parties by the Electoral Commission, and £686,000 set aside in the new financial year to fight the elections on May 23.
author: christopherhope

text:
Wrigley's Extra chewing gum is selling for 99p a stick in WH Smith's St Pancras Station this morning!

How is this possible? Is it early 'punishment" for a no-deal Brexit next week?

Anyone know what the inflationary factors are on a stick of Extra? The price seems very volatile.
author: christopherhope

text: Fresh guidance running to 23 pages has been made available to political parties by the Electoral Commission, and £686,000 set aside in the new financial year to fight the elections on May 23.
author: christopherhope

text: Britain's political parties have been formally told by the electoral regulator to prepare to fight the European Parliament elections in two months' time as fears of a lengthy delay to Brexit grow.
author: christopherhope

Amazing how the Spring Staemt has been completely forgotten by this evening.
This is not normal.

text: Britain could take part in European Parliament elections says Theresa May. "The House needs to face up to the consequences of its actions," says Mrs May. Opposition MPs shout angrily: "You do!" Absolute scenes in the House of Commons right now.

text: Theresa May says "the legal default" is to leave without a deal unless MPs take action. Opposition MPs shout "resign". Extraordinary scenes. #Brexit

text:
I thought @maitlis was on top form last night and fully articulating the exasperation of voters.
Emily Maitlis Loses it with Barry Gardiner on Newsnight https://order-order.com/2019/03/13/emily-maitlis-loses-barry-gardiner-newsnight/ … via @GuidoFawkes
author: christopherhope

text: This opens the door to a 'pay as you go' Brexit - which is deliverable
author: christopherhope

text:
Significant because it is a standstill agreement to leave the EU without a deal on 29 March and keep EU regulations unchanged for 21 months while UK negotiates a trade deal.
Put another way it is effectively a 'pay as you go' Brexit - with no EU permissions sought or required.
author: christopherhope

text:
MPs voted on 29th January to reject a no deal by accepting Caroline Spelman's amendment: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/01/29/brexit-vote-amendment-result-theresa-may-brady-cooper-news/ …
But the Govt carried out as though nothing happened.
How will today's vote be any different? Both were non-binding motions.
author: christopherhope

text: Hugely significant
author: christopherhope

text: This amendment is the 'standstill no deal Brexit' ie the UK leaves on March 29 with no deal but agrees to abide by EU rules unilaterally for 21 months.
author: christopherhope

text: Jeremy Hunt clearly wants to be the next leader
author: christopherhope

text:
Tomorrow's free vote on a no deal Brexit is the biggest for Conservative MPs since the free vote on gay marriage in 2013.

Tory MPs who want to be leader know that a vote against a no deal will seriously damage their chances of succeeding.
author: christopherhope

text: Asked if the PM was the right person to lead the country going into Brexit her spokesman has just said: "The House of Commons as a whole has quite recently expressed its confidence in the Government which is of course led by the Prime Minister." Make of that what you will #Brexit
author: christopherhope

text: The PM's long statement to MPs after another huge defeat distilled in five words: "It's not me, it's you."#BrexitShambles
author: christopherhope

text: One Tory MP tells me his colleagues will consider whether they will go to see Theresa May in a delegation to say that it is time to resign to reboot the Brexit talks. It could be a long night.
author: christopherhope

text: My source was one vote out.
author: christopherhope

text: Theresa May says MPs will vote for delaying Brexit on Thursday
author: christopherhope

text: Theresa May confirms tomorrow's vote on leaving without will be a free vote. The PM is losing control of events. #Brexit
author: christopherhope

text: BREAKING Theresa May's deal is voted down 391 to 242. Majority of 149. One of the biggest reversals in history.
author: christopherhope

text: One ministerial source: "Significant numbers" have voted against the deal. "
author: christopherhope

text: NEW One MP says just three Labour MPs have rebelled as voted for the deal.
author: christopherhope

text: DUP MPs have now voted in the No lobby. One MP who has just left says "she is going down big".
author: christopherhope

text: NEW One Tory MP votes in black tie telling us moments afterwards: "This is what they wore on the Titanic."
author: christopherhope

text: One Labour MP says the Government is facing a "massive" defeat tonight.
author: christopherhope

text:
BREAKING David Davis MP WILL back Theresa May's deal tonight. This is a major win for the Prime Minister.
But it won't be enough. Senior Government figure says they expect the deal to be voted down by a majority of nearly 150.
author: christopherhope

text: NEW Will Quince MP who quit as PPS over the original deal will back Theresa May's revised deal tonight
author: christopherhope

text:
The Telegraph's forecast on tonight's vote so far, compiled by the excellent @horton_official:

For: 98
Against: 146
Undecided: 14

ie just 20 Tory MPs have switched sides from voting against to planning to vote for Theresa May's deal. This is not a bandwagon with any momentum.
author: christopherhope

text: NEW John Bercow: "When the Speaker is on his feet a Member should not be on his or her feet. I wouldn't want your audience to think that's the Speaker being pompous or self-important ..."
author: christopherhope

text: . @JohnnyMercerUK will vote for Theresa May's deal tonight
author: christopherhope

text: I accepted the polo
author: christopherhope

text: Yes
author: christopherhope

text:
Parliament is in ferment. In the past half an hour I have managed to interrupt two groups of four of five Tory MPs who were anxiously discussing what on earth is going to happen next. 
The tension was only broken when Michael Gove walked up to us and said: "Anyone want a polo?"
author: christopherhope

text: Amazing
author: christopherhope

text: In the old days the Chancellor would sip from a glass of whisky mid-Budget. Can Phil Hammond offer Theresa May a tot at the dispatch box? She certainly needs one.
author: christopherhope

text:
NEW Looks like DUP is confirming its MPs will vote against tonight.

DUP spokesman says: "Having carefully considered the published material ...  it is clear that the risks remain that the UK would be unable to lawfully exit the backstop were it to be activated."
author: christopherhope

text:
The @LibDems has already started to select their candidates. Nigel Farage's @BrexitParty_UK has a slate ready to go. 
And the Electoral Commission has set aside £829,000 to help fight them.
The @Telegraph revealed the scale of the forward planning last May https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/05/26/government-quietly-planning-britain-stay-eu-march-deadline-eurosceptics/ …
author: christopherhope

text:
Talk is turning to tomorrow's likely vote on exiting without a deal.

Ministers are falling over themselves to say they will back a no deal if it is a free vote.

For Tory grassroots activists it will be the most important test for MPs since gay marriage was legalised in 2013.
author: christopherhope

text: Well well well. Geoffrey Cox is a very principled man. The easy choice would be to back Mrs May's deal. But he hasn't.
author: christopherhope

text: And if you ask your smart speaker to play the latest editition of Chopper's Brexit Podcast - it will! @brexitbroadcast
author: christopherhope

text: Thank you I Want To Break Free!
author: christopherhope

text: NEW Singing 'I Vow To Thee My Country' makes inner city pupils feel proud to be British, says headteacher https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/08/singing-vow-thee-country-makes-inner-city-pupils-feel-proud/?WT.mc_id=tmg_share_tw … via @Telegraph
author: christopherhope

text: Dodds: "This is an attempt to get ahead of a possible blame game and appear positive when in reality it is going backwards to something rejected a year ago."
author: christopherhope

text:
The day just gets worse for PM Theresa May.

DUP Deputy Leader Nigel Dodds MP says the UK rejected Barnier's offer a year ago: “This is neither a realistic nor sensible proposal from Michel Barnier.  It disrespects the constitutional and economic integrity of the United Kingdom."
author: christopherhope

text: Three in one day. Dominated the afternoon Lobby meeting with the PM's spokesman. Very rare for three Cabinet ministers to make such public errors in a short 24 hour period. Are they too distracted by Brexit?
author: christopherhope

text:
No mention in the House of Commons Business for next week of any debate about leaving without a deal (Wednesday) or delaying Brexit (Thursday).
Which will fuel suggestions that this rumour could be true...

text: Labour MP Chris Bryant in tears as he reveals his cancer battle on live TV' | via @telegraph https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/06/labour-mp-chris-bryant-breaks-tears-reveals-cancer-battle-live/ … By Maighnu Nanu
author: christopherhope

text:
This would allow a third meaningful vote the following week just days before Brexit day, following in swift succession by the no deal and extension votes.

One MP tells me: “They want to pull it and have another go.”
author: christopherhope

text:
Latest rumour: Theresa May could pull the vote on 'no deal' on Wednesday and to extend Brexit on Thursday if she narrowly loses the meaningful vote on Tuesday, MPs say. 
A draft plan for low key debates has been drafted by officials for Wednesday and Thursday if votes are pulled.
author: christopherhope

text: I've got a few I can think of...
author: christopherhope

text: But Conservative campaigner John Strafford tells me: "This is clearly nonsense. How can you ask for something to be put on the Agenda until you have received Notice of when the meeting is? ... there is nothing in the Party's Constitution to stop this normal practice."

text:
Welcome back to the Government Robert Goodwill, the new Environment minister!
Fourteen months ago he was sacked as Children's minister after six months in the job, saying that Theresa May was“making way for younger people”.

text: Emmanuel Macron's article in the Guardian today summarises in 1,000 words why Brexiteers want to leave the EU, which he describes twice as a "project" not an economic union, and lists his ideas for several new pan-EU bodies taking power away further away from voters.

text: Tory party activists are kicking off after Theresa May opened the door to a delay to Brexit this week. Expect more of these votes through AGM season for Tory parties. The careers of some Conservative MPs are now on the line.
author: christopherhope

text: Activists are expected to request a vote on Dame Caroline’s future at her party’s annual meeting next Friday; Mark Pawsey faces a vote on his future on March 20 and Dominic Grieve has to win a vote of no confidence on March 29.
author: christopherhope

text: The Telegraph can disclose that three Tory MPs Dame Caroline Spelman, Dominic Grieve and Mark Pawsey are facing no confidence motions at their party's annual meetings over the next four weeks.
author: christopherhope
